content.raw: Do we need this line? The `ign_pkg_check_modules_quiet(OGRE ... )` macro will call [`pkg_check_modules(OGRE ...)`](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.5/module/FindPkgConfig.html) which will set a variable named `OGRE_VERSION`. If you just remove this `execute_process(~)` call and then move the string logic to after line 53, I believe it should work just as effectively.
content.html: Do we need this line? The ign_pkg_check_modules_quiet(OGRE ... ) macro will call pkg_check_modules(OGRE ...) which will set a variable named OGRE_VERSION. content.raw:
I gave this a try and the build went through but IgnUtils.cmake produces a warning:

~~~
CMake Warning (dev) at /home/osrf/code/ian/ign_ws/devel/lib/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/IgnUtils.cmake:1611 (message):


  The build script has specified some unrecognized arguments for
  ign_string_append(~):

  Terrain;Overlay)

  Either the script has a typo, or it is using an unexpected version of
  ign-cmake.  The version of ign-cmake currently being used is 0.3.0

Call Stack (most recent call first):
  /home/osrf/code/ian/ign_ws/devel/lib/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/IgnUtils.cmake:459 (_ign_cmake_parse_arguments)
  /home/osrf/code/ian/ign_ws/devel/lib/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/IgnUtils.cmake:299 (ign_string_append)
~~~

Printing out `${${PACKAGE_NAME}_find_dependency}` gives:

~~~
find_package(OGRE \${{ign_package_quiet}} \${{ign_package_required}} COMPONENTS RTShaderSystem;Terrain;Overlay)
~~~

So looks like the semi-column delimited `${ign_find_package_COMPONENTS}` string is probably the cause of this problem?

content.raw:
By the way, if you decide to go this route, I recommend reading `OGRE_FIND_COMPONENTS` with a for-loop, something like:

```
foreach(component ${OGRE_FIND_COMPONENTS})
  ign_pkg_check_modules_quiet(OGRE-${component} "OGRE-${component} >= ${full_version}")
  if(OGRE-${component}_FOUND)
    list(APPEND OGRE_LIBRARIES OGRE-${component}::OGRE-${component})
  else()
    set(OGRE_FOUND false)
  endif()
endforeach()
```

Then you can get rid of the individual logic for `RTShaderSystem`, `Terrain`, and `Overlay`.
content.html:
By the way, if you decide to go this route, I recommend reading OGRE_FIND_COMPONENTS with a for-loop, something like:

foreach(component ${OGRE_FIND_COMPONENTS})
  ign_pkg_check_modules_quiet(OGRE-${component} "OGRE-${component} >= ${full_version}")
  if(OGRE-${component}_FOUND)
    list(APPEND OGRE_LIBRARIES OGRE-${component}::OGRE-${component})
  else()
    set(OGRE_FOUND false)
  endif()
endforeach()

Then you can get rid of the individual logic for RTShaderSystem, Terrain, and Overlay.

content.raw:
Unfortunately, not really. This find-module will be called in `ignition-rendering-config.cmake`, so the logic would have to be put into that config-file as well. That immediately becomes a much bigger pain to maintain.

We should actually discourage people from copying our find-modules as-is. These find-modules are being developed with the assumption that they're only being used for ignition projects. In this case, for example, we're completely ignoring many components of OGRE (if I'm not mistaken) because we're only looking for the ones we care about. Creating a general-purpose find-module for OGRE would be a big chore, and we should only consider doing that if we can get buy-in from the OGRE maintainers and merge it upstream to them. We may even want to consider renaming our find-module to `FindIgnOGRE.cmake` and then calling `ign_find_package(IgnOGRE ...)` from our projects.

All that being said, if you do want to make this find-module more modular with respect to the OGRE components, we can do something like

```
ign_find_package(
  OGRE
  COMPONENTS RTShaderSystem Terrain Overlay
  REQUIRED_BY ogre
  PRIVATE_FOR ogre)
```

Then in this find-module you can check which components are listed as required by checking the variable `OGRE_FIND_COMPONENTS`. That variable will automatically be provided to your find-module by the `find_package(~)` command. If any of the requested components are missing, then you should set `OGRE_FOUND` to false.
content.html:
Unfortunately, not really. This find-module will be called in ignition-rendering-config.cmake, so the logic would have to be put into that config-file as well. That immediately becomes a much bigger pain to maintain.

We should actually discourage people from copying our find-modules as-is. These find-modules are being developed with the assumption that they're only being used for ignition projects. In this case, for example, we're completely ignoring many components of OGRE (if I'm not mistaken) because we're only looking for the ones we care about. Creating a general-purpose find-module for OGRE would be a big chore, and we should only consider doing that if we can get buy-in from the OGRE maintainers and merge it upstream to them. We may even want to consider renaming our find-module to FindIgnOGRE.cmake and then calling ign_find_package(IgnOGRE ...) from our projects.

All that being said, if you do want to make this find-module more modular with respect to the OGRE components, we can do something like

ign_find_package(
  OGRE
  COMPONENTS RTShaderSystem Terrain Overlay
  REQUIRED_BY ogre
  PRIVATE_FOR ogre)

Then in this find-module you can check which components are listed as required by checking the variable OGRE_FIND_COMPONENTS. That variable will automatically be provided to your find-module by the find_package(~) command. If any of the requested components are missing, then you should set OGRE_FOUND to false.

content.raw:
Awesome! It's great to see the components branch getting some use. I see that you're already using `REQUIRED_BY` and `PRIVATE_FOR` in `ign_find_package(~)`, so that's fantastic.

In anticipation of these components being required, it might be a good idea to set `OGRE_FOUND` to `false` whenever one of the components is missing. Technically that doesn't need to be done now if they aren't actually required yet, but it'll probably be safer now than waiting until they're actually required.
content.html:

Technically that doesn't need to be done now if they aren't actually required yet, but it'll probably be safer now than waiting until they're actually required.

content.raw:
ogre has its own [FindOGRE.cmake](https://bitbucket.org/sinbad/ogre/src/2852667eb60cf3db0f92b93be58b8ffe0ee69b92/CMake/Packages/FindOGRE.cmake?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) file but I think  there're a few reasons that we're not using it:

1) it depends on a few macros that are defined in other files so we may need to pull in a few other files

2) there've been a few cmake changes between ogre versions and so I'm not sure if there is a generic `FindOGRE.cmake` file that works for all versions of OGRE. 

There's some logic in its `FindOGRE.cmake` file for getting `plugindir` information. I could look into copying those logic into our own cmake file. Probably later in a separate PR once I set up a windows machine

2) there've been a few cmake changes between ogre versions and so I'm not sure if there is a generic FindOGRE.cmake file that works for all versions of OGRE.

There's some logic in its FindOGRE.cmake file for getting plugindir information. I could look into copying those logic into our own cmake file. Probably later in a separate PR once I set up a windows machine

content.raw:
This sounds... unfortunate... especially for end-users. Based on a quick glance over OGRE's use of cmake, their cmake scripts look very crusty and old fashioned, so there might not be much we can do about this, short of making revisions to OGRE's cmake scripts and submitting a pull request to them. Still, we should try to pay attention to see if OGRE ever offers a more elegant way for us to get this directory information.

Edit: I just noticed they're using cmake version 2.8.6, so it's little wonder that they're not using modern features of cmake.

content.raw:
Any variables that you set inside of `FindOGRE.cmake` will also be set in the scope of any `CMakeLists.txt` file that calls `find_package(OGRE)`, or in our case `ign_find_package(OGRE)`. It doesn't seem to be well documented by cmake, but find-modules (as well as config-files) use "dynamic scoping" for their variables, similar to the [`include`](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.5/command/include.html) command. So any variables that you read or write in a find-module will be read or written in the scope of the caller.

There are only three hypothetical advantages to setting it as a cache variable:

1. The variable can persist between invocations of `cmake`

2. The variable can be used in a scope which is a parent of the `CMakeLists.txt` file that calls `find_package(OGRE)`

3. Users can override the value of the variable

These three hypothetical advantages are actually disadvantages for us, for the following (respective) reasons:

1. It's much safer to re-find dependencies in between invocations of `cmake`. Sometimes if you reinstall a package or anything else changes in your build environment, cmake can get confused if it tries to work off of some cached package variables, forcing you to clear the `CMakeCache.txt` for no obvious reason. Also, the time required to re-find dependencies is usually negligible anyway.

2. We **always** want to call `ign_find_package( ... )` from the highest-level scope, so this should never be useful.

3. There should be no reason for a user to ever want to override the value of the variable, and allowing them to will most likely cause far more harm than benefit, unless there's a very specific reason to.
content.html:
Any variables that you set inside of FindOGRE.cmake will also be set in the scope of any CMakeLists.txt file that calls find_package(OGRE), or in our case ign_find_package(OGRE). It doesn't seem to be well documented by cmake, but find-modules (as well as config-files) use "dynamic scoping" for their variables, similar to the include command. So any variables that you read or write in a find-module will be read or written in the scope of the caller.

There are only three hypothetical advantages to setting it as a cache variable:

  1. The variable can persist between invocations of cmake

  2. The variable can be used in a scope which is a parent of the CMakeLists.txt file that calls find_package(OGRE)

  3. Users can override the value of the variable

These three hypothetical advantages are actually disadvantages for us, for the following (respective) reasons:

  1. It's much safer to re-find dependencies in between invocations of cmake. Sometimes if you reinstall a package or anything else changes in your build environment, cmake can get confused if it tries to work off of some cached package variables, forcing you to clear the CMakeCache.txt for no obvious reason. Also, the time required to re-find dependencies is usually negligible anyway.

  2. We always want to call ign_find_package( ... ) from the highest-level scope, so this should never be useful.

  3. There should be no reason for a user to ever want to override the value of the variable, and allowing them to will most likely cause far more harm than benefit, unless there's a very specific reason to.

content.raw: Same, `ign-cmake` will also automatically print out whenever a package was not found. Moreover, `ign-cmake` never calls `find_package(~)` with the `REQUIRED` argument, because we want to gracefully handle failure to find a package by identifying all of the dependencies that are missing and then printing a list of them out to the user.
content.html: Same, ign-cmake will also automatically print out whenever a package was not found. Moreover, ign-cmake never calls find_package(~) with the REQUIRED argument, because we want to gracefully handle failure to find a package by identifying all of the dependencies that are missing and then printing a list of them out to the user.
